newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS - Straddles traded in Barclays, NatWest.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Straddles traded in Barclays, NatWest.

text.p: One of the main deals in the UK stock options market on Wednesday afternoon concerned a short straddle in Barclays Bank against a long straddle in National Westminster Bank, dealers said.

The short straddle in Barclays involved selling 500 December 850 puts and calls at 10p and 97p each for 107p credit and for maximum profit this requires the underlying shares to go down to 850p by December expiry.
The long straddle in NatWest concerned the purchase of 640 October 650 puts and calls at 11p and 43p each making a net debit of 54p.
For the long position to be profitable at expiry NatWest shares need to either go below 596p or above 704p.
By 1405 GMT NatWest shares had fallen 15p to 674p while those of Barclays were down 14p to 917p.
Over in tobacco-to-insurance group BAT Industries, one trader believing the recent share price fall had been overdone, established a synthetic long position.
This involved buying 250 November 460 calls at 27p and selling 250 November puts at 19p and at expiry the deal will make money if BAT shares go above 468p.
Elsewhere, in food retailer Sainsbury (J) there was a buyer of 1,200 October 390 puts at 5p. The shares fell 8p to 399p.
In contrast there was a buyer of 1,000 October 500 calls in retailer Marks & Spencer at 13p and 15p and the underlying shares slipped 5-1/2p to 493-1/2p.
Today's expiry of August stock options -- at 1510 GMT -- accounted for much of the rest of business and included closing deals in Lucas Industries, GEC and Vodafone.
